Logical Foundations - Properties of Relations

Posted by Hux on January 11, 2019

relation ä¸injective/surjective/bijective function ç­‰ç›¸å…³çš„çŸ¥è¯†åœ¨ 5. Tactics é‡Œï¼Œä¸ºäº†é¿å…æ¯æ¬¡éƒ½è¦ grep æˆ‘åœ¨è¿™é‡Œå†™ä¸€ä¸‹ã€‚

Relations

Recalling Relation

from FCT/TAPL/Wikiâ€¦

a possible connection between the components of a k-tuple.

I have been long confused with Unary Relations vs. Binary Relation on the Same Set (homogeneous relation) I thought they were sameâ€¦but turns out they are totally different!

Unary/1-place relation is Predicate or Property!

Either defined via set X âŠ† P or x âˆˆ P, or defined via function P : X -> Bool or P : X -> {âŠ¥, âŠ¤}. (usually used in Math. Logic)

Property = Indicator Fn = characteristic Fn = Boolean Predicate Fn = Predicate

  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Property_(mathematics)
  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indicator_function

Binary Relation/2-place relation

Defined via two sets : R âŠ† X Ã— Y or x, y âˆˆ R or xRy. (where x âˆˆ X, y âˆˆ Y.) or via function R: X Ã— Y -> Bool.

Homogeneous Relation åŒç±»ï¼ˆçš„ï¼‰å…³ç³»

Specifically! when X = Y, is called a homogeneous relation:

Noticed that we are still concerning relations of 2 elements!!, but they are from the same Set! (while 1-place relation concerning only 1 element.)

1
2

R âŠ† X Ã— X
xRy where x âˆˆ X, y âˆˆ X

itâ€™s written/spoken Binary relation on/over Set X. Properties e.g. reflexive, symmetric, transitive, are all properties of â€œHomogeneous Relationâ€!

Back to Coq

â€œrelationâ€ is a general idea. but in Coq standard lib it means â€œbinary relation on a set Xâ€

Coq identifier relation will always refer to a binary relation between some set and itself.

itâ€™s defined as a family of Prop parameterized by two elements of X:

1
2
3
4

Definition relation (X: Type) := X â†’ X â†’ Prop.

Check le : nat -> nat -> Prop.
Check le : relation nat.

Basic Properties

ways to classifying relations. so theorems can be proved generically about certain sorts of relations

Itâ€™s pretty fun to see all mathematical things defined in Coq! (much more constructive)

Partial Function

function is defined as a special kind of binary relation.

1
2

Definition partial_function {X: Type} (R: relation X) :=
  âˆ€x y1 y2 : X, R x y1 â†’ R x y2 â†’ y1 = y2.

meaning that foreach input x âˆˆ X, there is a unique y âˆˆ Y corresponded.

But this only establish a partial function. because it doesnâ€™t say anything about totality, to define total function, we require f map every x âˆˆ X.

  • Total â€œRelationâ€

    âˆ€x âˆ€y (x âˆˆ X âˆ§ y âˆˆ X) â‡’ (xRy âˆ¨ yRx).

totally different with total function but ask the binary relation holds between every pair.

Reflexive

1
2

Definition transitive {X: Type} (R: relation X) :=
  âˆ€a b c : X, (R a b) â†’ (R b c) â†’ (R a c).

Transitive

1
2

Definition transitive {X: Type} (R: relation X) :=
  âˆ€a b c : X, (R a b) â†’ (R b c) â†’ (R a c).

Symmetric & Antisymmetric

1
2
3
4
5

Definition symmetric {X: Type} (R: relation X) :=
  âˆ€a b : X, (R a b) â†’ (R b a).
  
Definition antisymmetric {X: Type} (R: relation X) :=
  âˆ€a b : X, (R a b) â†’ (R b a) â†’ a = b.

Antisymmetric vs Asymmetric vs Non-symmetric (åå¯¹ç§° vs. éå¯¹ç§° vs. ä¸-å¯¹ç§°)

A relation is asymmetric if and only if it is both antisymmetric and irreflexive e.g. <= is neither symmetric nor asymmetric, but itâ€™s antisymmetricâ€¦ åå¯¹ç§°: å¯ä»¥è‡ªå (åªèƒ½ reflexive æ—¶å¯¹ç§°) <= éå¯¹ç§°: ä¸èƒ½è‡ªå < ä¸å¯¹ç§°: ä¸æ˜¯å¯¹ç§°

Equivalence

1
2

Definition equivalence {X:Type} (R: relation X) :=
  (reflexive R) âˆ§ (symmetric R) âˆ§ (transitive R).

Partial Orders

A partial order under which every pair of elements is comparable is called a total order or linear order In the Coq standard library itâ€™s called just order for short:

1
2

Definition order {X:Type} (R: relation X) :=
  (reflexive R) âˆ§ (antisymmetric R) âˆ§ (transitive R).

Preorders

a.k.a quasiorder

The subtyping relations are usually preorders.

(TAPL p185) because of the record permutation ruleâ€¦there are many pairs of distinct types where each is a subtype of the other.

1
2

Definition preorder {X:Type} (R: relation X) :=
  (reflexive R) âˆ§ (transitive R).

Reflexive, Transitive Closure

Closure Closure can be considered as Operations on bin-rel

As properties such as reflexive, transitive, the blah blah Closure are only talking about â€œhomogeneous relationsâ€ i.e., Relation on a SINGLE set.

Reflexive Closure

Def. smallest reflexive relation on X containing R.

Operationally, as a = operator on a binary relation R:

1

Râ¼ = R âˆª {â€‰(x, x) | x âˆˆ Xâ€‰}

and this obviously satisfy Râ¼ âŠ‡ R.

Transitive Closure

Def. smallest transitive relation on X containing R.

Operationally, as a + operator on a binary relation R:

1

R+ = R âˆª { (x1,xn) | n > 1 âˆ§ (x1,x2), ..., (xn-1,xn) âˆˆ R }

We can also constructively and inductively definition using R^i where i = i-transitivity away.

Reflexive, Transitive Closure

1

R* = Râ¼ âˆª R+

Why is it useful?

The idea is that a relation is extended s.t. the derived relation has the (reflexsive and) transitive property. â€“ Prof. Arthur

e.g. the â€œdescendantâ€ relation is the transitive closure of the â€œchildâ€ relation, the â€œderives-star (â‡’â‹†)â€ relation is the reflexive-transitive closure of the â€œderives (â‡’)â€ relation. the â€œÎµ-closureâ€ relation is the reflexive-transitive closure of the â€œÎµ-transitionâ€ relation. the â€œKleene-star (Î£â‹†)â€ relation is the reflexive-transitive closure of the â€œconcatentationâ€ relation.

Another way is to think them as â€œset closed under some operationâ€.

Back to Coq

1
2
3
4
5
6
7

Inductive clos_refl_trans {A: Type} (R: relation A) : relation A :=
  | rt_step x y (H : R x y) : clos_refl_trans R x y        (** original relation **)
  | rt_refl x : clos_refl_trans R x x                      (** reflexive  xRx              **)
  | rt_trans x y z                                         (** transitive xRy âˆ§ yRz â†’ xRz  **)
        (Hxy : clos_refl_trans R x y)
        (Hyz : clos_refl_trans R y z) :
        clos_refl_trans R x z.

The above version will generate 2 IHs in rt_trans case. (since the proof tree has 2 branches).

Here is a better â€œlinked-listâ€-ish one. (we will exclusively use this style)

1
2
3
4
5
6

Inductive clos_refl_trans_1n {A : Type} (R : relation A) (x : A) : A â†’ Prop :=
  | rt1n_refl : clos_refl_trans_1n R x x
  | rt1n_trans (y z : A)
      (Hxy   : R x y) 
      (Hrest : clos_refl_trans_1n R y z) :
      clos_refl_trans_1n R x z.

In later chapter, we will define a decorator multi that can take any binary relation on a set and return its closure relation:

1
2
3

Inductive multi (X : Type) (R : relation X) : relation X :=
  | multi_refl : forall x     : X,                         multi R x x
  | multi_step : forall x y z : X, R x y -> multi R y z -> multi R x z

We name it step, standing for doing one step of this relation, and then we still have the rest (sub-structure) satisfied the closure relation.
